image.altText: Two people holding big fish.

title.children: Darwin barramundi facility aims to cut waste, reduce food miles

image.altText: Neil Gaughan at a Senate Committee.

image.altText: An out of focus man and woman walk past a building with glass sliding doors and a sign reading Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The RBA's latest quarterly Statement on Monetary Policy shows its decision to leave rates on hold at 4.1 per cent in August was a close call, and is taking a "wait and see" approach for future interest rate meetings.

title.children: RBA plays wait and see as Australia's economy hangs in the balance

image.altText: Two women walking and smiling next to a large flag displaying the Commonwealth Games Federation logo

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Commonwealth Games Federation 'sorry to hear' about Canadian cancellation — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Earlier we brought you news of the Canadian province of Alberta withdrawing its bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games, citing overwhelming costs. The Commonwealth Games Federation has since released a statement, in which it says it is "sorry to hear that Alberta is no longer developing its bid proposal". It also says it has been reviewing its timeline after the Victorian government withdrew as 2026 host last month. "We thank all those who worked on Alberta’s inspiring and comprehensive plan and we believe the province could be a fantastic host for the Commonwealth Games in the future," the federation says. "We had already been reviewing our selection timeline as a result of the recent Victorian government decision. The dialogue with other potential hosts is ongoing."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Games Federation responds to Canadian province withdrawing from 2030 games

children.content: Earlier we brought you news of the Canadian province of Alberta
withdrawing its bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games
, citing overwhelming costs.
The Commonwealth Games Federation has since released a statement, in which it says it is "sorry to hear that Alberta is no longer developing its bid proposal".
It also says it has been reviewing its timeline
after the Victorian government withdrew as 2026 host last month.
"We thank all those who worked on Alberta’s inspiring and comprehensive plan and we believe the province could be a fantastic host for the Commonwealth Games in the future," the federation says.
"We had already been reviewing our selection timeline as a result of the recent Victorian government decision. The dialogue with other potential hosts is ongoing."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Niger's ousted leader has urged the US and "international community" to help "restore constitutional order" after last week's coup. In an opinion piece published in the Washington Post, President Mohamed Bazoum says he is writing "as a hostage". Earlier, thousands of people demonstrated in Niger's capital Niamey to show their support for last week's military coup, including some who were holding Russian flags. It comes on the 63rd anniversary of the country's independence from France. Niger's junta says it has revoked various military cooperation agreements with France, which has between 1,000 and 1,500 troops in the country helping to fight an insurgency by groups linked to al Qaeda and Islamic State. Niger was seen as the West's last reliable partner in the region, but some in the country see Russia and its Wagner mercenary group, which operates in a handful of African countries, as a powerful alternative.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Niger's ousted president says he is 'a hostage', as demonstrators raise Russian flags in the capital

children.content: Niger's ousted leader has urged the US and "international community" to help "restore constitutional order" after last week's coup.
In an opinion piece published in the Washington Post,
President Mohamed Bazoum says he is writing "as a hostage"
Earlier, thousands of people demonstrated in Niger's capital Niamey to show their support for last week's military coup, including some who were holding Russian flags.

It comes on the 63rd anniversary of the country's independence from France.
Niger's junta says it has revoked various military cooperation agreements with France
, which has between 1,000 and 1,500 troops in the country helping to fight an insurgency by groups linked to al Qaeda and Islamic State.

Niger was seen as the West's last reliable partner in the region, but some in the country see Russia and its Wagner mercenary group, which operates in a handful of African countries, as a powerful alternative.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Canadian province of Alberta has withdrawn its support for a bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games, citing overwhelming costs. The decision is another blow for the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) after the Canadian city of Hamilton (which hosted the inaugural Games in 1930) suspended its bid and Australia's Victorian government last month withdrew as host of the 2026 Games due to projected cost overruns. The Alberta bid was scuttled for similar reasons, Reuters reports. "We promised to remain transparent with Albertans about the costs of hosting international sporting events and clearly demonstrating a return on our investment for the people and communities of Alberta," wrote Mackenzie Blyth, press secretary to the Minister of Tourism and Sports Joseph Schow in an email to CBC. "In the case of the 2030 Commonwealth Games, the numbers just didn't add up for our government to commit taxpayer's money with the games estimated to cost $CA2.68 billion ($3.1 billion)."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'The numbers didn't add up': Canadian province withdraws bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games

props.alt: A Canadian female athlete walks and smiles next to someone carrying a large Canadian flag, during a Commonwealth Games ceremony

children.content: (AP: Kirsty Wigglesworth)
The Canadian province of Alberta has withdrawn its support for a bid to host the 2030 Commonwealth Games, citing overwhelming costs.

The decision is another blow for the Commonwealth Games Federation (CGF) after the Canadian city of Hamilton (which hosted the inaugural Games in 1930) suspended its bid and Australia's Victorian government last month withdrew as host of the 2026 Games due to projected cost overruns.
The Alberta bid was scuttled for similar reasons, Reuters reports.

"We promised to remain transparent with Albertans about the costs of hosting international sporting events and clearly demonstrating a return on our investment for the people and communities of Alberta," wrote Mackenzie Blyth, press secretary to the Minister of Tourism and Sports Joseph Schow in an email to CBC.
"In the case of the 2030 Commonwealth Games, the numbers just didn't add up for our government to commit taxpayer's money with the games estimated to cost $CA2.68 billion ($3.1 billion)."

image.altText: Suncorp accepts a $4.9 billion offer from ANZ for its banking business

title.children: ACCC rejects ANZ's $4.9b takeover of Suncorp, Amazon earnings surge, ASX flatlines at open

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This was another question put to Treasury officials during the cost of living committee hearing by Senator Jane Hume. Treasury's forecast for GDP (or economic growth) in the May budget was 3.25% for the 2022-23 financial year, and Senator Hume asked if that was going to be achieved. Ineke Redmond from Treasury said they still needed to compile and review data to form a more thorough assessment, but said developments including population growth (including migration) could see an increase in GDP, if not equalling that forecast, despite a slightly sharp fall in consumption because of inflation and interest rates. Treasury's Luke Yeaman also reiterated Ms Redmond's comments and said overall the economy was tracking "quite close" to its growth forecasts. Mr Yeaman said while he wouldn't attribute a number to economic growth right now, the economy was developing broadly in line with its expectations as forecast in the budget. (For what it's worth, the RBA's just released economic outlook within its August Statement on Monetary Policy shows the central bank is now expecting a year-average GDP growth to be 3% for the 2022-23 financial year .)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Treasury's economic growth forecast on track?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A brief hello from me — I've spent the morning listening to the Select Committee on the Cost of Living, where senators were asking Treasury officials about all things inflation and living cost pressures (as the name might suggest). Committee member senator Karen Grogan asked Treasury's Luke Yeaman whether the federal budget handed down in May was inflationary. Mr Yeaman explained that the economy had been seeing a substantial fiscal contraction, which had helped to take the pressure off inflation, and the budget contained measures that helped to reduce inflation (like rent, childcare and electricity bill assistance). He said Treasury's overall sense was that the budget was not adding to inflation, and that had also been the general reaction from financial markets. This line of questioning was also picked up by the committee chair, senator Jane Hume, who asked if the budget was "deflationary". Mr Yeaman responded that the budget was "broadly neutral" and reiterated that there was a substantial contraction and explained that while fiscal policy did have some lagging elements that took time to flow through, there were contractionary elements that were also coming through to keep inflation lower. He again explained that electricity prices, childcare and Commonwealth rental assistance were having direct downwards impacts while inflation and CPI was high. He said he understood the comments around the budget, but maintained that Treasury's stance was that the budget was helping bring inflation down. (I also wrote about what impact the federal budget could have on interest rates and inflation after it was handed down — you can have a read of that below.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasury officials maintain that federal budget not adding to inflation

featuredLink.title: Budget heightens risk for the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates 'at least once' in coming months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two hours into the local session, and the ASX 200 remains very near the flatline — at last check just two points lower. That's despite a good showing by the energy sector, after oil prices rallied overnight. Energy names dominate the best performing stocks, alongside Domino's Pizza (+2.8%) and Tabcorp (+2.4%). And on the flipside Block (-10.5%) and ResMed (-10.2%) continue to lag. In response to the ACCC decision to block a $4.9 billion takeover deal, ANZ shares are up 0.6 per cent, roughly in line with gains for some of the other banks, while Suncorp shares have pared early losses to be down 0.3 per cent. And the Australian dollar has risen modestly, up 0.4 per cent to around 65.8 US cents.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy leading ASX, Aussie dollar higher
